document.title: Maryland College and Career Ready Standards for English Language Arts Grades 6-8

A036CC88247E4AB59AE5D8F304329C5B.description:
Acquire and use accurately grade
appropriate general academic and domainspecific words and phrases; gather vocabulary
knowledge when considering a word or phrase
important to comprehension or expression.

2AF8611A1D65498B97E4A0AF19C754B3.description:
Distinguish among the
connotations (associations) of words
with similar denotations (definitions)
(e.g., bullheaded, willful, firm, persistent,
resolute).

7A402C4EF18D4C139C6F8BC74910E9E1.description:
Use the relationship between
particular words to better understand
each of the words.

930B62346A0C4C93AC9B9E453AFA1EC1.description:
Interpret figures of speech (e.g.
verbal irony, puns) in context.

3EEB8E705F574D77A318AAA87B06913A.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative
language, word relationships, and nuances in
word meanings.

016FA60917AF4E0DBF031462542B43AD.description:
Verify the preliminary
determination of the meaning of a word or
phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred
meaning in context or in a dictionary).

F4C39491408B4443ADFAA15EB594F375.description:
Consult general and specialized
reference materials (e.g., dictionaries,
glossaries, thesauruses), both print and
digital, to find the pronunciation of a word
or determine or clarify its precise meaning
or its part of speech.

8B1BF283792D4A2695C5A639A44BE67C.description:
Use common, grade-appropriate
Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to
the meaning of a word (e.g., precede,
recede, secede).

6638709260CB47ABAD2C6E9767E4B422.description:
Use context (e.g., the overall
meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a
word's position or function in a sentence)
as a clue to the meaning of a word or
phrase.

58ABC47A079D48A08747C37B0A8539F1.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of
unknown and multiple meaning words or
phrases based on grade 8 reading and
content, choosing flexibly from a range of
strategies.

69B184BE824645D29DBF517D7FB04B61.description:
Use verbs in the active and passive
voice and in the conditional and
subjunctive mood to achieve particular
effects (e.g., emphasizing the actor or the
action; expressing uncertainty or
describing a state contrary to fact).

9851CF882E7D4F20963DB340C098C56B.description:
Use knowledge of language and its
conventions when writing, speaking, reading,
or listening.

24F89AAFCF8D401F8AD8CC1C0303FFC2.description:
Use an ellipsis to indicate an
omission.

DE890B8226564A2F9ABF525E85EC46F2.description:
Use punctuation (comma, ellipsis,
dash) to indicate a pause or break.

63B265DCF7AE46AB8EE287CC03F354C9.description:
Demonstrate command of the
conventions of standard English capitalization,
punctuation, and spelling when writing.

801E68625FAE44DF80E6D22A90E17E2B.description:
Recognize and correct
inappropriate shifts in verb voice and
mood. *

6F63D42244CE4F4BA7D15C95613B204B.description:
Form and use verbs in the
indicative, imperative, interrogative,
conditional, and subjunctive mood.

658494F433164AADB933D358ED8E9517.description:
Form and use verbs in the active
and passive voice.

E259C8663647491CA6E61C3AB4A4B1B4.description:
Explain the function of verbals
(gerunds, participles, infinitives) in general
and their function in particular sentences.

7BBBA809728346B9B15D8C66D226001B.description:
Demonstrate command of the
conventions of standard English grammar and
usage when writing or speaking.

F46C04A753754B0A8FE8B3D5ECC9DA58.description:
Adapt speech to a variety of contexts
and tasks, demonstrating command of formal
English when indicated or appropriate. (See
grade 8 Language standards 1 and 3 for specific
expectations.)

A13170C778AB4C59A7B74AF08947E79B.description:
Integrate multimedia and visual displays
into presentations to clarify information,
strengthen claims and evidence, and add
interest.

F7442BAF62C740B486D32F185BC582A5.description:
Present claims and findings,
emphasizing salient points in a focused,
coherent manner with relevant evidence,
sound valid reasoning, and well-chosen details;
use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume,
and clear pronunciation.

10DA212A3D57403684D72C3DD3107765.description:
Delineate a speaker's argument and
specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the
reasoning and relevance and sufficiency of the
evidence and identifying when irrelevant
evidence is introduced.

44E246D5C7064BD5B8CC45B8E3AD1EE8.description:
Analyze the purpose of information
presented in diverse media and formats (e.g.,
visually, quantitatively, orally) and evaluate the
motives (e.g., social, commercial, political)
behind its presentation.

6CB000B1D37043EF8E551453750A041E.description:
Acknowledge new information
expressed by others, and, when
warranted, qualify or justify their own
views in light of the evidence presented.

904B74E3C4BD4AF9A7FAE3F516226592.description:
Pose questions that connect the
ideas of several speakers and respond to
others' questions and comments with
relevant evidence, observations, and
ideas.

059ED6DF898442B38E67096932BFB0FB.description:
Follow rules for collegial
discussions and decision-making, track
progress toward specific goals and
deadlines, and define individual roles as
needed.

68A89E81E8D543508EE2CD04E72860A6.description:
Come to discussions prepared,
having read or researched material under
study; explicitly draw on that preparation
by referring to evidence on the topic, text,
or issue to probe and reflect on ideas
under discussion.

C7A4081204634A7B8C0E8E5DFB80AFDD.description:
Engage effectively in a range of
collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in
groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners
on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on
others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.

06DD012436414B61A23ACB0312FC9F3A.description:
Write routinely over extended time
frames (time for research, reflection, and
revision) and shorter time frames (a single
sitting or a day or two) for a range of disciplinespecific tasks, purposes, and audiences.

A5882991D12B42BFAF20D6CD38A4BFF9.description:
Apply grade 8 Reading standards
to literary nonfiction (e.g., "Delineate and
evaluate the argument and specific claims
in a text, assessing whether the reasoning
is sound and the evidence is relevant and
sufficient; recognize when irrelevant
evidence is introduced").

093CF84187364F0DA56E2077AB3ED7DD.description:
Apply grade 8 Reading standards
to literature (e.g., "Analyze how a modern
work of fiction draws on themes, patterns
of events, or character types from myths,
traditional stories, or religious works such
as the Bible, including describing how the
material is rendered new").

9892E77C5BEF41408D9BC1D66841F276.description:
Draw evidence from literary or
informational texts to support analysis,
reflection, and research.

4F1D2F5C1D2D4366AD05B39A7749C9E0.description:
Gather relevant information from
multiple print and digital sources, using search
terms effectively; assess the credibility and
accuracy of each source; and quote or
paraphrase the data and conclusions of others
while avoiding plagiarism and following a
standard format for citation.

F9C5F06AFBA04D249CFC8A8161FDD6AB.description:
Conduct short research projects to
answer a question (including a self-generated
question), drawing on several sources and
generating additional related, focused
questions that allow for multiple avenues of
exploration.

0C905D80BA8D4FC895E15E6D39E96E52.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

D0B466C938D24EB686D43A3E6253BE2F.description:
Use technology, including the Internet,
to produce and publish writing and present the
relationships between information and ideas
efficiently as well as to interact and collaborate
with others.

04B05993B40A4A15974F1F735D445DB2.description:
With some guidance and support from
peers and adults, develop and strengthen
writing as needed by planning, revising,
editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach,
focusing on how well purpose and audience
have been addressed. (Editing for conventions
should demonstrate command of Language
standards 1-3 up to and including grade 8.)

96A6FE581BD543F9AB63AE29106FB907.description:
Produce clear and coherent writing in
which the development, organization, and
style are appropriate to task, purpose, and
audience. (Grade-specific expectations for
writing types are defined in standards 1-3
above.)

C155AE9E9E4942DCBEFCB75193577A64.description:
Provide a conclusion that follows
from and reflects on the narrated
experiences or events.

88C0417631AA4301868B0554A7BFEAC5.description:
Use precise words and phrases,
relevant descriptive details, and sensory
language to capture the action and convey
experiences and events.

26E800B4F84647DAB121B27AE119D861.description:
Use a variety of transition words,
phrases, and clauses to convey sequence,
signal shifts from one time frame or
setting to another, and show the
relationships among experiences and
events.

85B8A885BACF439BBDB7613C35EE0B5C.description:
Use narrative techniques, such as
dialogue, pacing, description, and
reflection, to develop experiences, events,
and/or characters.

301D6583AAB84DC0BE7B6849472347BE.description:
Engage and orient the reader by
establishing a context and point of view
and introducing a narrator and/or
characters; organize an event sequence
that unfolds naturally and logically.

2BF17F9F9B5641EAAE9CEA46106436AB.description:
Write narratives to develop real or
imagined experiences or events using effective
technique, relevant descriptive details, and
well-structured event sequences.

C00499774D7F4D87AAF75450624B4C09.description:
Provide a concluding statement or
section that follows from and supports the
information or explanation presented.

BE7A9B0EFED54922859CDCDC9C34881E.description:
Establish and maintain a formal
style.

0E1B1BDA72244E83A5A4AA2F702451A0.description:
Use precise language and
domain-specific vocabulary to inform
about or explain the topic.

3E796ADEE2B44B1F8292760B4F56F009.description:
Use appropriate and varied
transitions to create cohesion and clarify
the relationships among ideas and
concepts.

C2EFA72C1CA14A75913067744BFFCCA1.description:
Develop the topic with relevant,
well-chosen facts, definitions, concrete
details, quotations, or other information
and examples.

5EDAC1E00CDC4A6EB293EF4D305CDFD3.description:
Introduce a topic clearly,
previewing what is to follow; organize
ideas, concepts, and information into
broader categories; include formatting
(e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts,
tables), and multimedia when useful to
aiding comprehension.

8B10AF34CD2E4165A46B76D72DCEA88F.description:
Write informative/explanatory texts to
examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts,
and information through the selection,
organization, and analysis of relevant content.

0093CA138B504437A09FD1DD2245841E.description:
Provide a concluding statement
or section that follows from and supports
the argument presented.

95080366288B47F895FF295320C0E63E.description:
Establish and maintain a formal
style.

B4CCDAB50C244A3BAF7D74826A0DC0AB.description:
Use words, phrases, and clauses
to create cohesion and clarify the
relationships among claim(s),
counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

C84F493AAEF94F88A43CC1E7E6F581D3.description:
Support claim(s) with logical
reasoning and relevant evidence, using
accurate, credible sources and
demonstrating an understanding of the
topic or text.

29EC1E74424E416EB4EC0C791D6DAAE9.description:
Introduce claim(s), acknowledge
and distinguish the claim(s) from alternate
or opposing claims, and organize the
reasons and evidence logically.

A49965858D06473CBC89E285B0C98731.description:
Write arguments to support claims with
clear reasons and relevant evidence

6F6EA9C5CA7940048646FAEC4A65D12D.description:
By the end of the year, read and
comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end
of the grades 6-8 text complexity band
independently and proficiently.

3D505B5AE95041CC8B98C4AE0C9C0047.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

640189EC735D4D58B5E7A31DF1332102.description:
Analyze a case in which two or more
texts provide conflicting information on the
same topic and identify where the texts
disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.

E9457C1592F44BEBBC8B88C48393855E.description:
Delineate and evaluate the argument
and specific claims in a text, assessing whether
the reasoning is sound and the evidence is
relevant and sufficient; recognize when
irrelevant evidence is introduced.

8AED7BEDD0E5411FB307C344385316BC.description:
Evaluate the advantages and
disadvantages of using different mediums (e.g.,
print or digital text, video, multimedia) to
present a particular topic or idea.

4DD09B2455A64F929C2583CB4B57DEEC.description:
Determine an author's point of view or
purpose in a text and analyze how the author
acknowledges and responds to conflicting
evidence or viewpoints.

10001DA37B6A40F9BED457F895E5FF3E.description:
Analyze in detail the structure of a
specific paragraph in a text, including the role
of particular sentences in developing and
refining a key concept.

E780C81B28BB4327B2F5091DE6CB98A0.description:
Determine the meaning of words and
phrases as they are used in a text, including
figurative, connotative, and technical
meanings; analyze the impact of specific word
choices on meaning and tone, including
analogies or allusions to other texts.

6B0C7B577313429BA0F3D1B1727DFD0B.description:
Analyze how a text makes connections
among and distinctions between individuals,
ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons,
analogies, or categories).

F41B969A09DD47D49E5D864E099A8DC0.description:
Determine a central idea of a text and
analyze its development over the course of the
text, including its relationship to supporting
ideas; provide an objective summary of the
text.

AEC395E287FF4191B43A4AB03648C7F3.description:
Cite the textual evidence that most
strongly supports an analysis of what the text
says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from
the text.

2FB6B4A25A6945B8BBE7CBE05C5F2CB3.description:
By the end of the year, read and
comprehend literature, including stories,
dramas, and poems, at the high end of grades
6-8 text complexity band independently and
proficiently.

4A487DCC0B9B47928252B9251C57660C.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

CAC02741B6BD4491862E997CC6C8832E.description:
Analyze how a modern work of fiction
draws on themes, patterns of events, or
character types from myths, traditional stories,
or religious works such as the Bible, including
describing how the material is rendered new.

8F40E168A54D461084C74BA10480B31E.description:
Analyze the extent to which a filmed or
live production of a story or drama stays
faithful to or departs from the text or script,
evaluating the choices made by the director or
actors.

AF671C0DE77046599FB491EEC65F49ED.description:
Analyze how differences in the points of
view of the characters and the audience or
reader (e.g., created through the use of
dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense
or humor.

9FAC234A493A4D1EB41B6F7E75D6C179.description:
Compare and contrast the structure of
two or more texts and analyze how the
differing structure of each text contributes to
its meaning and style.

E3AE0B2AFC2A484292D2C8EDD2F7BAC9.description:
Determine the meaning of words and
phrases as they are used in a text, including
figurative and connotative meanings; analyze
the impact of specific word choices on meaning
and tone, including analogies or allusions to
other texts.

158AEDB947DF46B794DEDA7309D1CD19.description:
Analyze how particular lines of dialogue
or incidents in a story or drama propel the
action, reveal aspects of a character, or
provoke a decision.

7F54FC4C186C4BAE873ADDA0400137A0.description:
Determine a theme or central idea of a
text and analyze its development over the
course of the text, including its relationship to
the characters, setting, and plot; provide an
objective summary of the text.

C4039FD6AEE24C4E8B955FD8E4729B63.description:
Cite the textual evidence that most
strongly supports an analysis of what the text
says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from
the text.
